metadata.synopsis: Players try to uncover the hidden messages in the Orpheus Chapters. They will be able to automatically decipher them if they have received Chapter 2 from the Gith Boy or found the Gith Cipher in the Underdark.Once a chapter has been set as Read, the true story will be available as a book the next time they interact with the item.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Pick up or read any of the still locked Orpheus Chapters

15.speaker: Narrator
15.text: *The disc is similar to one you found before - and similarly baffling.*

33.speaker: Narrator
33.text: *The disc is formed from slate and engraved with githyanki writing.*

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *It closely resembles the disc that Lae'zel deciphered.*

69.speaker: Narrator
69.text: *You examine them closely, but can't make much sense of them.*

1.speaker: Narrator
1.text: *The symbols are striking to look at, but you aren't sure what they mean.*

3.speaker: Narrator
3.text: *The disc from Crèche Y'llek was distinctly similar to this one. If you can match the symbols, you might find a legible pattern.*

64.speaker: Player
64.text: Command the disc to reveal its secrets.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: Compare the disc to the one from the crèche.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: Use the cipher you found to decode the symbols.

9.speaker: Narrator
9.text: *A pattern forms as you gaze at the disc, and from within that pattern, a story emerges.*

25.speaker: Narrator
25.text: *It is another chapter in the tale of the githyanki prince called Orpheus.*

34.speaker: Narrator
34.text: *'The Prince of the Comet, Part One.'*
34.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

59.speaker: Narrator
59.text: *'So it was that we were free from ghaik shackles and turned our blades on each other. The heavens were shattered, and one great empire was divided in two.'*
59.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

38.speaker: Narrator
38.text: *'Gith travelled to the Hells to broker help for her people, her cause. Vlaakith would have you believe Mother Gith proclaimed her our queen.'*
38.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

45.speaker: Narrator
45.text: *'Lies! Gith made no such proclamation. Vlaakith seized the empire against the Mother's wishes.'*
45.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

68.speaker: Narrator
68.text: *'But Gith had nurtured a son. Orpheus, Prince of the Comet, the True Heir! He knew Vlaakith's treachery.'*
68.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

53.speaker: Narrator
53.text: *'Orpheus rallied Gith's honour guard and declared the throne for himself. The War of the Comet had begun.'*
53.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

21.speaker: Narrator
21.text: *It's an intriguing tale - and a forbidden one, given how expertly it was encoded.*

29.speaker: Narrator
29.text: *Lae'zel will surely want to know of this.*

18.speaker: Narrator
18.text: *'The Prince of the Comet, Part Three.'*

35.speaker: Narrator
35.text: *'The histories tell us that Commander Voss, Jhe'stil Kith'rak, pierced Prince Orpheus clean through with his sword of silver. That his flesh was torn and fed to the great red dragon Ephelomon.'*
35.context: NodeContext: Reading a story, matter of factly. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

54.speaker: Narrator
54.text: *'Vlaakith's faithful roar out this tale. But beneath the roars, we hear whispers carrying truth and prophecy.'*
54.context: NodeContext: reading from a book, matter of factly

31.speaker: Narrator
31.text:
*'The Prince of the Comet is not dead.
The Prince of the Comet will come again.
The Prince of the Comet will liberate us from Vlaakith's tyranny.'*

44.speaker: Narrator
44.text: *'Praise be to Mother Gith, Queen of the One Sky! Praise be to your son Orpheus, the True Heir, Prince of the Comet!'*

20.speaker: Narrator
20.text: *It's an intriguing tale - and a forbidden one, given how expertly it was encoded.*

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Seek a pattern in the writing.

22.speaker: Narrator
22.text: *In your mind's eye, the symbols trade places with each other until a clear pattern forms. And from that pattern, a story emerges.*

0.speaker: Narrator
0.text: *No matter how hard you try, you can't make any sense of the symbols.*

5.speaker: Narrator
5.text: *You should take the disc to Lae'zel. She might know more about it.*

66.speaker: Player
66.text: Recall your language lessons, try to arrange the symbols in a coherent order.

26.speaker: Narrator
26.text: *You recall a method your ancestors used to conceal information from its illithid slavers and apply it to the disc. From the symbols, a pattern forms - and from that pattern, a story emerges.*

70.speaker: Narrator
70.text: *You don't recall any lessons in githyanki code-breaking.*

52.speaker: Player
52.text: Stash the disc in your pack.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Stash the disc in your pack.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Stash the disc in your pack.

42.speaker: Narrator
42.text: *Using the cipher you found, you might be able to reveal the disc's meaning.*

55.speaker: Narrator
55.text: *Without a cipher or primer to aid you, the disc's message could be near-impossible to discern.*

16.speaker: Narrator
16.text: *This time, the symbols easily resolve into coherent words and sentences. The story of Orpheus further unfolds.*

75.speaker: Narrator
75.text: *The chapter ends there. This disc might be of some interest to Lae'zel.*

67.speaker: Narrator
67.text: *The disc is similar to one you found before.*

74.speaker: Narrator
74.text: *Circular symbols are etched on the disc.*
